pullRequest.body:
Adds a term elaborator for `congr(...)` "congruence quotations". For example, if `hf : f = f'` and `hx : x = x'`, then we have `congr($hf $x) : f x = f' x'`. This supports the functions having implicit arguments, and it has support for subsingleton instance arguments. So for example, if `s t : Set X` are sets with `Fintype` instances and `h : s = t` then `congr(Fintype.card $h) : Fintype.card s = Fintype.card t` works.

Ports the `congrm` tactic as a convenient frontend for applying a congruence quotation to the goal. Holes are turned into congruence holes. For example, `congrm 1 + ?_` uses `congr(1 + $(?_))`. Placeholders (`_`) do not turn into congruence holes; that's not to say they have to be identical on the LHS and RHS, but `congrm` itself is responsible for finding a congruence lemma for such arguments.

---


<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

nodes.body: It's occurred to me that we should be able to implement `congrm` using `convert_to` and then benefit from all of the congruence machinery that's there. I'm going to go and investigate.

I have an experiment on the `mcdoll/congrm_kmill_experiment` branch [(diff)](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/compare/master...mcdoll/congrm_kmill_experiment). It uses a `congr%` term elaborator to turn the pattern into a congruence lemma and then applies it using `refine`, which lets it unfold definitions too.

It uses `?m` for pattern holes rather than `_`, like in `gcongr`, and a consequence is that (1) we can differentiate between what should be solved by unification and what by future goals and (2) we can name goal tags and solve specific ones with `case`.

It's not perfect yet, since it doesn't completely handle things like `Fintype` instance arguments, but at the moment it's passing the tests from this PR.
Thanks Kyle! This looks very nice. Feel free to merge it into this PR. I am extremely busy at the moment (I am at ESI in Vienna), so I will probably not find the time to do anything on this soon.

@semorrison It turned out to be tricky to write a reliable congruence quotation elaborator, but it seems to work now!

I haven't had a chance to do an in-depth review of my own code yet -- I've been staring at it too long too recently -- but if you can lend fresh eyes I'd appreciate it.
A nice test would be to try to remove all porting notes that mention `congrm` was used in mathlib3.

@PatrickMassot Good idea. All the porting notes are handled but the one in `Mathlib.Geometry.Euclidean.Angle.Sphere`, where it wasn't clear that `congrm` was better (I did check that `congrm` worked though).
Great!

Have you thought of having `apply_fun` also be implemented using congruence quotations?  `apply_fun` works on hypotheses and goals, equalities and inequalities, but here I mean specifically for equality hypotheses.

Not for this PR, just curious.
@hrmacbeth Yeah, `apply_fun f at h` ought to be equivalent to `replace h := congr(f $h)`.
This is really nice!
bors merge

Is this error message truncated?
Needs module doc.
Please move to Mathlib/Lean/Expr/Basic.lean
This is a bit weird. Usually we'd have an `Option.some` when a `try` succeeds, rather than the reverse? Does this really need its own function?
Not sure this really needs its own function; it's barely shorter than its definition!
You could do these three lines nicely with a `match  goal.applyWithFreshMVarLevels with`.
If you're immediately calling `.fvarId!`, wouldn't it make more sense to have an `FVarId` argument?
Unless the argument order matters for some other reason, I like the convention of `MVarId`s-come-last. It is often convenient for combining tactics, passing to `liftMetaTactic`, etc.
Why is this `partial`? Why does it have `telescoping` in the name? There's no recursive call.
Maybe you could track down the "somewhere"? :-)

```suggestion
initialize registerTraceClass `Tactic.congrm
```
We're wildly inconsistent about this, but I *think* putting `` `Tactic`` in the name is the more common approach.
Does this need an error message? If we haven't consumed the pattern yet the user probably should know about it!
Could you explain the logic here? If we're "failing", we should say so in some way, not just do nothing.
This should be turned on, and use #guard_msgs to check they fail in the right way.

You're allowed to return assigned metavariables with `liftMetaTactic`, so you can do something like this, if we want to avoid needing `tryRefl`:
```lean
for mvar in mvars do
  try discard <| mvar.refl catch _ => pure ()
return mvars
```
Whenever you get the main goal, it prunes assigned metavariables for you anyway.

```suggestion
  congrm fun x =>  w, ?_ + a = w
```
and elsewhere.
Could we have a test for it failing to unfold something irreducible?

```suggestion
  congrm fun x =>  w, ?_ + a = w
```
Word missing here? "is *built* from"?
Could you clarify "but whenever we can figure out a LHS or a RHS we unify"? It isn't obvious to me yet what this means.
That was a mysterious sentence, but I think I figured out what I meant.

```suggestion
2. Once the pattern has been elaborated twice, we unify against the LHS and RHS of the target type.
```
Just to avoid a slightly hard to dereference "these".
Is this different from `( inferType pfTy).isProp`?
Yeah, it has the side effect of making `pfTy` a proposition if its type is just a metavariable. I'm adding the comment "Ensure that `pfTy` is a proposition"

```suggestion
by replacing antiquotations with `cHole%` terms, and ensure the elaborated term
```
I couldn't follow this sentence.
Added clarification. "Kind" refers to a `CongrKind`, and this function uses `subsingletonInst` for arguments that are subsingletons for reasons other than being `Decidable` instances.
Is this something generally useful that maybe should be lifted out of this file for visibility?
Lifting it out would take a bit of work to do right (there are also some useful functions in `Mathlib.Tactic.Congr!` that ought to be lifted out). Is the TODO I left ok for now?

```suggestion
  throwError "Could not generate congruence between{indentD lhs}\nand{indentD rhs}"
```
I'm confused by this note.

This was a problem in `congr!` as well. I added some clarification.

The issue is that if you have `Sort ?u` then if there weren't `withNewMCtxDepth` then instance search is perfectly happy to unify this with `Prop` and say "yes, these are subsingletons". Without it, this would succeed:
```
example (T : Sort _) (x y : T) : x = y := congr(_)
```
Do these actually happen? I'm unclear if these are meant to be considered unreachable or just unfortunate. :-)

If it happens, it's really unfortunate, but I wouldn't expect it in normal operation. The expected type could be an equality with a metavariable shared between the LHS and RHS, letting a hole leak from the LHS to the RHS.

I don't really know how else this can occur in practice, but I figure one day someone on Zulip will let us know :wink:
Similarly here.

This is also not impossible, sadly. We always have the problem that the congruence hole could be given to an elaborator that reduces its argument in some way, stripping the annotation. These particular cases come up when that elaborator does it conditionally (what if `h : 1 = x` and `foo% 1` turns `1` into `Nat.succ Nat.zero` but leaves `foo% x` alone since it's not a number?).

```suggestion
Where they are desynchronized, we fall back to the base case (using `CongrResult.mkDefault'`)
```
Just making sure I understand here, the "since" means that congruence holes inside proofs wouldn't matter, and not fastforwarding in their presence is the "more conservative"?
Correct. I changed it to "since congruence holes might *only* be inside proofs" to try to make the meaning clearer

I guess you could remove the duplication here by writing a single function `res.or_or_heq kind` or something. Probably doesn't matter, but it would have saved my taking a moment to work out if anything was different.
Yeah, I'd considered trying to deduplicate, but what stopped me before is all these `mut` variables
Ah, indeed. Okay.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: `congr(...)` congruence quotations and port `congrm` tactic
